**Raymond Wallace Bolger** (January 10, 1904 – January 15, 1987)[2] was an
American actor, singer, and dancer (particularly of [tap](/wiki/Tap_dance "Tap
dance")) of vaudeville, stage (particularly musical theatre) and screen, who
started in the silent film era. He is best known for his portrayal of the
[Scarecrow](/wiki/Scarecrow_\(Oz\) "Scarecrow \(Oz\)") in MGM's classic _[The
Wizard of Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The Wizard of Oz \(1939
film\)")_ (1939). He was also the host of his own television show, _[The Ray
Bolger Show](/wiki/The_Ray_Bolger_Show "The Ray Bolger Show")_.[2]

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ray_Bolger&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Early life")]

Bolger was born into a [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic")
family of Irish descent in [Dorchester, Boston](/wiki/Dorchester,_Boston
"Dorchester, Boston"), the son of James Edward and Anne C. (née Wallace)
Bolger.[3][4]

His entertainment aspirations evolved from the [vaudeville](/wiki/Vaudeville
"Vaudeville") shows of his youth. He began his career in a vaudeville tap
show, creating the act "Sanford & Bolger" with his dance partner. In 1926, he
danced at New York City's legendary [Palace
Theatre](/wiki/Palace_Theatre_\(Broadway\) "Palace Theatre \(Broadway\)"), the
premier vaudeville theatre in the United States. His limber body and
improvisational dance movement won him many leading roles on Broadway in the
1930s. Eventually, his career would also encompass film, television and
nightclub work.[5] In 1932 he was elected to the theater club, [The
Lambs](/wiki/The_Lambs "The Lambs").[6]

## Early career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ray_Bolger&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early career")]

Bolger signed his first cinema contract with [MGM](/wiki/Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
"Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer") in 1936, and although _[The Wizard of
Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The Wizard of Oz \(1939 film\)")_
was early in his film career, he appeared in other movies of note. His best
known pre-Oz appearance was _[The Great Ziegfeld](/wiki/The_Great_Ziegfeld
"The Great Ziegfeld")_ (1936), in which he portrayed himself. He also appeared
in _[Sweethearts](/wiki/Sweethearts_\(1938_film\) "Sweethearts \(1938
film\)")_ (1938), the first MGM film in [Technicolor](/wiki/Technicolor
"Technicolor"), starring [Nelson Eddy](/wiki/Nelson_Eddy "Nelson Eddy"),
[Jeanette MacDonald](/wiki/Jeanette_MacDonald "Jeanette MacDonald"), and
[Frank Morgan](/wiki/Frank_Morgan "Frank Morgan"). He also appeared in the
[Eleanor Powell](/wiki/Eleanor_Powell "Eleanor Powell") vehicle
_[Rosalie](/wiki/Rosalie_\(film\) "Rosalie \(film\)")_ (1937), which also
starred Eddy and Morgan.

## _The Wizard of
Oz_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ray_Bolger&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section:
The Wizard of Oz")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/The_Wizard_of_Oz_Ray_Bolger_1939.jpg/215px-
The_Wizard_of_Oz_Ray_Bolger_1939.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Wizard_of_Oz_Ray_Bolger_1939.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Wizard_of_Oz_Ray_Bolger_1939.jpg "Enlarge")

Bolger as the Scarecrow

Bolger's MGM contract stipulated that he would play any part the studio chose.
However, he was unhappy when he was originally cast as the [Tin
Woodman](/wiki/Tin_Woodman "Tin Woodman") in the studio's 1939 feature film
adaptation of _[The Wizard of Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The
Wizard of Oz \(1939 film\)")_. The role of the
[Scarecrow](/wiki/Scarecrow_\(Oz\) "Scarecrow \(Oz\)") had already been
assigned to another dancing studio contract player, [Buddy
Ebsen](/wiki/Buddy_Ebsen "Buddy Ebsen"). In time, the roles were switched.
Bolger's face was permanently lined by wearing the Scarecrow's makeup.[7]

## Post-Oz film
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ray_Bolger&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Post-Oz film career")]

Following _Oz_ , Bolger moved to [RKO Pictures](/wiki/RKO_Pictures "RKO
Pictures").[8] In 1941, he was a featured act at the [Paramount
Theatre](/wiki/Paramount_Theatre_\(New_York_City\) "Paramount Theatre \(New
York City\)") in New York, working with the [Harry James
Band](/wiki/Harry_James_Band "Harry James Band"). He would do [tap
dance](/wiki/Tap_dance "Tap dance") routines, sometimes in a mock-challenge
dance with the band's pianist, [Al Lerner](/wiki/Al_Lerner_\(composer\) "Al
Lerner \(composer\)"). One day during this period, the Japanese attacked
[Pearl Harbor](/wiki/Pearl_Harbor "Pearl Harbor"), and Bolger's performance
was interrupted by President [Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin
D. Roosevelt")'s announcement of the news of the attack.[9] Bolger toured in
[USO](/wiki/USO "USO") shows with [Joe E. Lewis](/wiki/Joe_E._Lewis "Joe E.
Lewis") in the Pacific Theater during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World
War II"), and was featured in the [United Artists](/wiki/United_Artists
"United Artists") wartime film _[Stage Door
Canteen](/wiki/Stage_Door_Canteen_\(film\) "Stage Door Canteen
\(film\)")_.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 1946, he returned to MGM for a featured role in _[The Harvey
Girls](/wiki/The_Harvey_Girls "The Harvey Girls")_. Also that year, he
recorded a children's album, _[The
Churkendoose](http://www.kiddierecords.com/2007/archive/week_19.htm)_ ,
featuring the story of a misfit fowl ("part chicken, turkey, duck, and goose")
which teaches children that beauty is in the eye of the beholder and it "all
depends on how you look at things".[8]

## Broadway and
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ray_Bolger&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Broadway and television")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ray_Bolger_1963.JPG/170px-
Ray_Bolger_1963.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ray_Bolger_1963.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Ray_Bolger_1963.JPG "Enlarge")

Bolger in a publicity photo for _[The Bell Telephone
Hour](/wiki/The_Bell_Telephone_Hour "The Bell Telephone Hour")_ , 1963

Bolger's Broadway credits included _[Life Begins at
8:40](/wiki/Life_Begins_at_8:40 "Life Begins at 8:40")_ (1934), _[On Your
Toes](/wiki/On_Your_Toes "On Your Toes")_ (1936), _[By
Jupiter](/wiki/By_Jupiter "By Jupiter")_ (1942), _[All
American](/wiki/All_American_\(musical\) "All American \(musical\)")_ (1962)
and _[Where's Charley?](/wiki/Where%27s_Charley%3F "Where's Charley?")_
(1948), for which he won the [Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading
Actor in a
Musical](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Performance_by_a_Leading_Actor_in_a_Musical
"Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Musical") and in
which he introduced "Once in Love with Amy", the song often connected with
him. He repeated his stage role in the 1952 film version of the musical.[10]
He also made _[April in Paris](/wiki/April_in_Paris_\(film\) "April in Paris
\(film\)")_ (1952) with [Doris Day](/wiki/Doris_Day "Doris Day").

Bolger appeared in his own [ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American
Broadcasting Company") television sitcom with a variety show theme, _[Where's
Raymond?](/wiki/Where%27s_Raymond%3F "Where's Raymond?")_ (1953–1954), renamed
the second year as _[The Ray Bolger Show](/wiki/Where%27s_Raymond%3F "Where's
Raymond?")_ (1954–55).[11] He continued to star in several films, including
[Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney")'s remake of _[Babes in
Toyland](/wiki/Babes_in_Toyland_\(1961_film\) "Babes in Toyland \(1961
film\)")_ (1961).[8]

Bolger made frequent guest appearances on television, including the episode
"Rich Man, Poor Man" of the short-lived _[The Jean Arthur
Show](/wiki/The_Jean_Arthur_Show "The Jean Arthur Show")_ in 1966. In the
1970s, he had a recurring role as the father of Shirley Partridge ([Shirley
Jones](/wiki/Shirley_Jones "Shirley Jones")) on _[The Partridge
Family](/wiki/The_Partridge_Family "The Partridge Family")_ , and appeared in
_[Little House on the Prairie](/wiki/Little_House_on_the_Prairie_\(TV_series\)
"Little House on the Prairie \(TV series\)")_ as Toby Noe and also guest
starred on other television series such as _[Battlestar
Galactica](/wiki/Battlestar_Galactica_\(1978_TV_series\) "Battlestar Galactica
\(1978 TV series\)")_ and _[Fantasy Island](/wiki/Fantasy_Island "Fantasy
Island")_. In the late 1970's, reaching back to his Irish roots, Bolger played
in a commercial for Safeway Supermarket's "Scotch Buy" brand. It covered many
products ranging from canned food to paper towels to beer and cigarettes.
Bolger popularized the jingle, "Scotch Buy - taint fancy but it shore is
good."[12] His last television appearance was on _[Diff'rent
Strokes](/wiki/Diff%27rent_Strokes "Diff'rent Strokes")_ in 1984, three years
before his death.[8][13]

In his later years, he danced in a _[Dr Pepper](/wiki/Dr_Pepper "Dr Pepper")_
television commercial, and in 1985, he and [Liza Minnelli](/wiki/Liza_Minnelli
"Liza Minnelli"), the daughter of his _Oz_ co-star [Judy
Garland](/wiki/Judy_Garland "Judy Garland"), starred in _[That's
Dancing!](/wiki/That%27s_Dancing! "That's Dancing!")_, a film also written by
[Jack Haley, Jr.](/wiki/Jack_Haley,_Jr. "Jack Haley, Jr."), the son of [Jack
Haley](/wiki/Jack_Haley "Jack Haley"), who portrayed the [Tin
Man](/wiki/Tin_Woodman "Tin Woodman") in _The Wizard of Oz_.[8]

In 1998, a Golden Palm Star on the [Palm Springs,
California](/wiki/Palm_Springs,_California "Palm Springs, California"), [Walk
of Stars](/wiki/Palm_Springs_Walk_of_Stars "Palm Springs Walk of Stars") was
dedicated to him.[14]

He was a [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church"), and a
member of the Good Shepherd Parish and the Catholic Motion Picture Guild in
[Beverly Hills, California](/wiki/Beverly_Hills,_California "Beverly Hills,
California").[15]

Bolger was a staunch [Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\)
"Republican Party \(United States\)") who campaigned for [Richard
Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") in 1968.[16]

## Death and legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ray_Bolger&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Death and legacy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ray_%26_Gwendolyn_Bolger%27s_grave.JPG/220px-
Ray_%26_Gwendolyn_Bolger%27s_grave.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ray_%26_Gwendolyn_Bolger%27s_grave.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Ray_%26_Gwendolyn_Bolger%27s_grave.JPG "Enlarge")

Ray and Gwendolyn Bolger's grave at [Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver
City](/wiki/Holy_Cross_Cemetery,_Culver_City "Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver
City")

Bolger died of [bladder cancer](/wiki/Bladder_cancer "Bladder cancer") on
January 15, 1987, in Los Angeles, five days after his 83rd birthday.[2] He was
interred at [Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver
City](/wiki/Holy_Cross_Cemetery,_Culver_City "Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver
City") in the Mausoleum, Crypt F2, Block 35.[17] He was survived by his wife
of over 57 years, Gwendolyn Rickard. They had no children.[18]

At the time of his death, he was the last surviving _main_ _credited_ cast
member of _The Wizard of Oz_.[19] At Judy Garland's funeral, Bolger was the
only one of her Oz co-stars to be present. He joined [Harold
Arlen](/wiki/Harold_Arlen "Harold Arlen"), the composer of "Over the Rainbow",
and his wife [Anya Taranda](/wiki/Anya_Taranda "Anya Taranda"). They were
reported as among the last remaining guests at the conclusion of the
service.[20]

Whenever asked whether he received any residuals from telecasts of the 1939
classic, Bolger would reply: "No, just immortality. I'll settle for that."[21]
Bolger's Scarecrow is ranked among the "most beloved movie characters of all
time" by AMC and the American Film Institute.[22][23]

For his contributions to the film industry, Bolger received a [motion pictures
star](/wiki/List_of_actors_with_Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame_motion_picture_stars
"List of actors with Hollywood Walk of Fame motion picture stars") on the
[Hollywood Walk of Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "Hollywood Walk of
Fame") in 1960. The star is located at 6788 [Hollywood
Boulevard](/wiki/Hollywood_Boulevard "Hollywood Boulevard").[24]
